purpose: where theory, culture, language and strategy nerds can hang out and talk about what it means to MEAN something.
text: <@U0914MEN7|james> set the channel purpose: where theory, culture, language and strategy nerds can hang out and talk about what it means to MEAN something.

*Semiotics Department  Mission*

Semiotics is the study of “making meaning” - and as such, the Semiotics Dept will responsible for the collection, curation, communication, and cultivation of insights that will inform the foundational elements of our projects (the context -  why, who, and how), but also actively inspire by championing the project vision over the entire project lifecycle.  

*Semiotics Department Vision*

Semiotics is not a job, it is a functional role. The role of semiotician can be played by anyone who is willing to dig in and uncover the deeper roots of the problem. This person is responsible for shepherding the organic process of understanding the context of the problem - by helping the team to collectively identify patterns that will get us to an inspired solution. A semiotician must keep these ideas in the forefront of the team’s minds, and as the thinking naturally evolves, they are required to actively cultivate and capture this evolution. Lastly, the semiotician acts as a storyteller - marrying the utility of research with the beauty of narrative, exposing the meaning that drives exceptional work.

*Semiotics Department  2016 Goals* (a work in progress)

Develop and test run the Q-Deck. ← more on this later
Build a strategy process that spans agency project life cycle, from new biz to case study.
Apply this thinking broadly to non-client agency activities (from ops to culture to cuba)
Articulate an agency POV on how to articulate (and close) the gap between ‘inform' and ‘inspire’
note that this is doing a lot of the stuff that I’ve already been doing - facilitating discoveries with clients to better understand their world, ethnographic research, writing briefs, etc.

attachments.title: I Was an Under-Age Semiotician
attachments.text: Embracing semiotics came with certain costs, but it left an intoxicating sense that the everyday world contained a secret layer of meaning that could be deciphered with the right key.
attachments.fallback: The New York Times Link: I Was an Under-Age Semiotician

attachments.title: 'The Uncomfortable' Series from KK Studio Turns Everyday Product Designs Upside Down
attachments.text: An inversely curved chair seat, a super stacked fork, an inflatable door handle&mdash;these are only a few of the designs that have come out of KK Studios. In a series aptly titled "The Uncomfortable," designer Katerina Kamprani decides to design in a whole new way that some may call plain...
attachments.fallback: Core77: 'The Uncomfortable' Series from KK Studio Turns Everyday Product Designs Upside Down

text: "The series' intent is pretty straightforward: The goal is to re-design useful objects making them uncomfortable but usable and maintain the semiotics of the original item..."

text: <@U06DFL7BP|charlesv> pinned a message to this channel.
one of my favorite semiotic quandaries in modern culture are emoji - so much room for misinterpretation - but they keep adding more!

attachments.title: Selfie, Shrug, ROFL, Face Palm, Whiskey, Clowns and more among new emoji arriving in June
attachments.text:
New emoji are coming! The organization that approves new emoji before they hit your keyboard has just announced 72 more&nbsp;emoji which will be added to the Unicode standard (Unicode 9.0) later this month. This selection includes several fun additions, including those reflective of internet slang &ndash; for example, Rolling on the Floor Laughing &ndash; which has its roots in the acronym&nbsp;ROFL &ndash; is one of the upcoming emoji and shows a tilted smiley face with a wide mouth and closed eyes. Another surely popular addition will be the shrug, which people tend today to type out with&nbsp;symbols like&nbsp;&macr;_(&#12484;)_/&macr;.
Plus there is a&nbsp;clown face, a Pinocchio-like lying face with a growing nose, a cowboy, and several &ldquo;sick&rdquo; faces like a green nauseated face, a sneezing face, and a drooling face (which looks more sick than salivating.).

Among the people additions, the notable new arrivals will include a woman with a child, a dancing man that looks like Saturday Night Fever&rsquo;s John Travolta, a guy in a tux, a face palm, and the aforementioned shrug.

For hand gestures, we&rsquo;re at last&nbsp;getting the crossed fingers emoji, as well as handshakes, fist bumps, and a raised arm with a phone in hand for the &ldquo;selfie&rdquo; emoji, among other things.

There are also a number of new animals and food items, including the timely add of a gorilla, plus deer, fox, lizard, shark, butterfly, and more, plus tasty bacon and baguettes, pancakes, and salad (if you&rsquo;re being good), to name just a few.

Oh, and yes: there&rsquo;s now finally a whiskey glass for those days when a beer mug or martini simply doesn&rsquo;t reflect your drink of choice. (Aka: every day.)

There are also a ton more sports and travel options, like mopeds and scooters, karate, fencing, boxing, handball, wrestling, juggling, gymnast, and even water polo&hellip;because&hellip;uh, well I&rsquo;m sure someone plays water polo and was tired of typing that out. Oh and&nbsp;hey, the Summer Olympics are coming!
The new gold, silver and bronze medals will be handy for that, too.

This is only a partial list with some of&nbsp;the highlights, but you can browse the full list of new emoji here on the <http://Unicode.org|Unicode.org> website.
One thing that you won&rsquo;t see in the new standard? More diverse emoji.&nbsp;Unicode had already rolled out an update that&nbsp;includes a skin tone modifier, but it still features a lot of male characters in job and sports roles &ndash; something where it would be nice to at least choose from a man or a woman.
Other companies are also working to diversify their emoji. Facebook this week introduced new emoji to better reflect skin tones and gender, along with more emoji of females &ndash; including as a police officer, runner, surfer, pedestrian, and a swimmer. Google employees, meanwhile, have submitted a proposal to the Unicode Consortium asking them to add 13 new emoji that highlight &ldquo;the diversity of women&rsquo;s careers,&rdquo; featuring women working as doctors, scientists, in the technology industry and more.
However, before you get your hopes up too much about all these new characters: although the Unicode Consortium will approve&nbsp;these new emoji in the Unicode 9.0 on June 21, 2016, that doesn&rsquo;t mean that&rsquo;s when they&rsquo;ll arrive in emoji keyboard on your phone.
After that point, smartphone makers like Apple, Google and Microsoft can use add the new emoji into their own software. They then have to release that to the public via a software update.
Main image: mock-up from Emojipedia; remaining from <http://Unicode.org|Unicode.org>
attachments.fallback: TechCrunch Link: Selfie, Shrug, ROFL, Face Palm, Whiskey, Clowns and more among new emoji arriving in June

text: and a pregnant emoji for miss <@U0DCXC37U> !
One of my favorite things about emoji is that it’s the human language essentially going full circle back to hieroglyphs
<@U026PLK4S|matt> uploaded a file: <https://uncorked.slack.com/files/matt/F1DMM22KS/download.png|download.png> and commented: oh gawd
i’m just anticipating my socal surfer friends sending me the “call me hand"
huge hole in the emoji universe that one is going to fill
